SDK objectsÂ¶

Described below are the user-exposed components of the NetQASM SDK.

  • BaseNetQASMConnection

  • Qubit

  • EPRSocket

  • Futures:

    • Future

    • Array

    • RegFuture

  • Socket

Note that BaseNetQASMConnection and Socket are abstract base-classes. These are implemented specifically for a runtime, e.g. a simulator or hardware runtime. However, when using the SDK this is handled automatically if these are imported from netqasm.sdk.external. For example one might write an application as follows

from netqasm.sdk.external import NetQASMConnection, Socket

# Setup a classical socket
bob_socket = Socket("alice", "bob")

with NetQASMConnection('alice'):
   # Main application...

The classes NetQASMConnection and Socket will be different subclasses of the abstract classes, depending on which runtime is used. If for example the application is simulated using `SquidASM`_ and NetSquid, then the NetQASMConnection will in fact be the class squidasm.sdk.NetSquidConnection. These different classes expose the same set of functionalities. They only differ in the way they communicate with the underlying simulator. For more details see Running your first app.

NetQASM connectionÂ¶

TODO write about connections

class netqasm.sdk.connection.BaseNetQASMConnection(app_name, node_name=None, app_id=None, max_qubits=5, log_config=None, epr_sockets=None, compiler=None, return_arrays=True, _init_app=True, _setup_epr_sockets=True)
property app_name

Get the application name

property node_name

Get the node name

property app_id

Get the application ID

__enter__()

Used to open the connection in a context.

This is the intended behaviour of the connection. Operations specified using the connection or a qubit created with it gets combined into a subroutine, until either flush() is called or the connection goes out of context which calls __exit__().

# Open the connection
with NetQASMConnection(app_name="alice") as alice:
    # Create a qubit
    q = Qubit(alice)
    # Perform a Hadamard
    q.H()
    # Measure the qubit
    m = q.measure()
    # Flush the subroutine to populate the variable `m` with the outcome
    # Alternetively, this can be done by letting the connection
    # go out of context and move the print to after.
    alice.flush()
    print(m)
__exit__(exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb)

TODO describe

block()

Block until flushed subroutines finish

QubitÂ¶

TODO write about qubits

class netqasm.sdk.qubit.Qubit(conn, add_new_command=True, ent_info=None, virtual_address=None)
property qubit_id

Get the qubit ID

property entanglement_info

Get the entanglement info

property remote_entangled_node

Get the name of the remote node the qubit is entangled with. If not entanled, None is returned.

measure(future=None, inplace=False, store_array=True)

Measures the qubit in the standard basis and returns the measurement outcome.

Parameters

  • future (Future) â The future to place the outcome in

  • inplace (bool) â If inplace=False, the measurement is destructive and the qubit is removed from memory. If inplace=True, the qubit is left in the post-measurement state.

X()

Performs a X on the qubit.

Y()

Performs a Y on the qubit.

Z()

Performs a Z on the qubit.

T()

Performs a T gate on the qubit.

H()

Performs a Hadamard on the qubit.

K()

Performs a K gate on the qubit.

S()

Performs a S gate on the qubit.

rot_X(n=0, d=0, angle=None)

Performs a rotation around the X-axis of an angle n * pi / 2 ^ d If angle is specified n and d are ignored and a sequence of n and d are used to approximate the angle.

rot_Y(n=0, d=0, angle=None)

Performs a rotation around the Y-axis of an angle n * pi / 2 ^ d If angle is specified n and d are ignored and a sequence of n and d are used to approximate the angle.

rot_Z(n=0, d=0, angle=None)

Performs a rotation around the Z-axis of an angle n * pi / 2 ^ d If angle is specified n and d are ignored and a sequence of n and d are used to approximate the angle.

cnot(target)

Applies a cnot onto target. Target should be a qubit-object with the same connection.

Parameters

target (Qubit) â The target qubit

cphase(target)

Applies a cphase onto target. Target should be a qubit-object with the same connection.

Parameters

target (Qubit) â The target qubit

reset()

Resets the qubit to the state |0>

free()

Unallocates the qubit.

EPR socketÂ¶

TODO write about epr sockets

class netqasm.sdk.epr_socket.EPRSocket(remote_app_name, epr_socket_id=0, remote_epr_socket_id=0, min_fidelity=100)

Encapsulates the notion of an EPR socket which sets up a virtual circuit in the network when instantiated and can then be used for entanglement generation.

Parameters

  • remote_node_name (str) â Name of the remote node to entangle with.

  • epr_socket_id (int) â The identifier used for this socket.

  • remote_epr_socket_id (int) â The identifier used by the remote node.

  • min_fidelity (int) â The minimum desired fidelity of EPR pairs generated using this socket. Values are integers in the range 0-100.

create_context(number=1, sequential=False)

Creates EPR pairs with a remote node and handles each pair by the operations defined in a subsequent context, see example below.

Example

To create two pairs and measure both of these in the Hadamard basis one can do as follows:

with epr_socket.create_context(number=num) as (q, pair):
    q.H()
    m = q.measure()

NOTE: The sequential flag can be used to specify if the qubits should use the same virtual qubit and there only exists one at a time or not.

Parameters

  • number (int) â The number of pairs to create

  • post_routine (function) â

    Can be used to specify what should happen when entanglement is generated for each pair. The function should take three arguments (conn, q, pair) where * conn is the connection (e.g. self) * q is the entangled qubit (of type netqasm.qubit._FutureQubit) * pair is a loop register stating which pair is handled (0, 1, â¦)

    for example to state that the qubit should be measured in the Hadamard basis one can provide the following function

    def post_create(conn, q, pair):
    q.H()
    q.measure(future=outcomes.get_future_index(pair))

    where outcomes is an already allocated array and pair is then used to put the outcome at the correct index of the array.

    NOTE: If the a qubit is measured (not inplace) in a post_routine but is also used by acting on the returned objects of createEPR this cannot be checked in compile-time and will raise an error during the execution of the full subroutine in the backend.

  • sequential (bool, optional) â

    If this is specified to True each qubit will have the same virtual address and there will maximally be one pair in memory at a given time. If number is greater than 1 a post_routine should be specified which consumed each pair.

    NOTE: If sequential is False (default), number cannot be greater than

    the size of the unit module. However, if sequential is True is can.

recv_context(number=1, sequential=False)

Receives EPR pair with a remote node (see doc of create_context())

property conn

Get the underlying NetQASMConnection

property remote_app_name

Get the remote application name

property remote_node_id

Get the remote node ID

property epr_socket_id

Get the EPR socket ID

property remote_epr_socket_id

Get the remote EPR socket ID

property min_fidelity

Get the desired minimum fidelity

create(self, number=1, post_routine=None, sequential=False, tp=EPRType.K, random_basis_local=None, random_basis_remote=None)

Creates EPR pair with a remote node

Parameters

  • number (int) â The number of pairs to create

  • post_routine (function) â

    Can be used to specify what should happen when entanglement is generated for each pair. The function should take three arguments (conn, q, pair) where * conn is the connection (e.g. self) * q is the entangled qubit (of type netqasm.qubit._FutureQubit) * pair is a loop register stating which pair is handled (0, 1, â¦)

    for example to state that the qubit should be measured in the Hadamard basis one can provide the following function

    def post_create(conn, q, pair):
    q.H()
    q.measure(future=outcomes.get_future_index(pair))

    where outcomes is an already allocated array and pair is then used to put the outcome at the correct index of the array.

    NOTE: If the a qubit is measured (not inplace) in a post_routine but is also used by acting on the returned objects of createEPR this cannot be checked in compile-time and will raise an error during the execution of the full subroutine in the backend.

  • sequential (bool, optional) â

    If this is specified to True each qubit will have the same virtual address and there will maximally be one pair in memory at a given time. If number is greater than 1 a post_routine should be specified which consumed each pair.

    NOTE: If sequential is False (default), number cannot be greater than

    the size of the unit module. However, if sequential is True is can.

  • tp (EPRType) â

    What type of request, i.e. either K (create and keep), M (measure-directly) or R (remote state preparation). Depending on the type of request the method will return different things, for example if the request is of type K a list of qubits will be returned:

    qubits = epr_socket.create(number=3, tp=EPRType.K)
for q in qubits:
    q.H()

    however for type M requests it will be a list of entanglement generations:

    ent_infos = epr_socket.create(number=3, tp=EPRType.K)
for ent_info in ent_infos:
    assert isinstance(ent_info, tuple)

recv(self, number=1, post_routine=None, sequential=False, tp=EPRType.K)

Receives EPR pair with a remote node (see doc of create())

class netqasm.sdk.classical_communication.socket.Socket(app_name, remote_app_name, socket_id=0, timeout=None, use_callbacks=False, log_config=None)

Socket used to communicate classical data between applications.

__init__(app_name, remote_app_name, socket_id=0, timeout=None, use_callbacks=False, log_config=None)

Socket used to communicate classical data between applications.

abstract send(msg)

Sends a message to the remote node.

abstract recv(block=True, maxsize=None)

Receive a message from the remote node.

send_structured(msg)

Sends a structured message (with header and payload) to the remote node.

Parameters

msg (StructuredMessage) â

Return type

None

recv_structured(block=True, maxsize=None)

Receive a message (with header and payload) from the remote node.

Return type

StructuredMessage

send_silent(msg)

Sends a message without logging

Return type

None

recv_silent(block=True, maxsize=None)

Receive a message without logging

recv_callback(msg)

This method gets called when a message is received.

Subclass to define behaviour.

NOTE: This only happens if self.use_callbacks is set to True.

conn_lost_callback()

This method gets called when the connection is lost.

Subclass to define behaviour.

NOTE: This only happens if self.use_callbacks is set to True.
